material.mattext: $$\mathbf{\dot x} = \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & 0 & a \ 0 & 0 & 0 \ 0 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \ 0 & 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{B} \mathbf{u}, \quad y = \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{C} \mathbf{x}$$ Is this system:
Unstable (internally and in the input-output sense)
Exponentially stable
Marginally stable
BIBO stable, but not internally stable
Stability properties depend on

Given the two continuous time systems: $$\begin{aligned}\label{sys1a} \mathbf{\dot x} =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & -1 \ 0 & -2 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \ 0 \end{array} \right] u_1, \quad y_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} \ \mathbf{\dot z} =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & 0 \ 0 & -2 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{z} + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \ 0 \end{array} \right] u_2, \quad y_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{z}\end{aligned}$$

Are these systems:
Unrelated
Algebraically equivalent (second system is diagonalization of first)
Zero-state equivalent but not algebraically equivalent
Dual systems

Given the two continuous time systems: $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\dot x} =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 0 \ 1 & -1 & 0 \ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \ 0 \ 0 \end{array} \right] u_1, \quad y_1 = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 1 & 0 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} \ \mathbf{\dot z} =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 \ 1 & 0 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{z} + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \ 0 \end{array} \right] u_2, \quad y_2 = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 2 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{z}\end{aligned}$$

Are these systems:
Unrelated
Algebraically equivalent
Zero-state equivalent but not algebraically equivalent
Dual systems

Given the continuous time system: $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\dot x} =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & \omega \ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} + \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 \ 1 \end{array} \right] u, \quad y = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x} \end{aligned}$$ Using a state feedback , which values of and place the closed-loop system’s poles in -1 and -0.5?
and
and
and
and

Given the discrete time system: $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}[k+1] =& \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & -0.5 & 0 \ 0 & 0.5 & 1 \ 0 & 0 & 1 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{x}[k] + \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 & 1 \ 0 & 0 & 0 \ 0 & 1 & -1 \end{array} \right] \mathbf{u}[k] \end{aligned}$$ What is the length of the shortest input sequence that can transfer the system from any state to any desired state?
No sequence of limited length can do this in general

Given the discrete time system: $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{x}[k+1] =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0.9 & 0.2 \ -0.5 & 0.9 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x}[k] + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{c} 1 \ 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{B} u[k] + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 \ 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{G} \mathbf{w}[k] \ y[k] =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 1 & 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{C} \mathbf{x}[k] + v[k]\end{aligned}$$ with the following disturbance and noise properties: $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{E}[\mathbf{w}[k]] =& 0, \quad \mathbf{E}[\mathbf{w}[k]\mathbf{w}[l]] = \delta[k,l]\mathbf{Q} \ \mathbf{E}[v[k]] =& 0, \quad \mathbf{E}[v[k]v[l]] = \delta[k,l]\sigma^2\end{aligned}$$

You are using a discrete time Kalman filter to estimate the states of
the system. If the apriori covariance matrix at time <img class="equation_image" title="k" src="/k" alt="LaTeX: k" data-equation-content="k"> is
<img class="equation_image" title="P^-[k] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array} \right]" src="/P%255E-%255Bk%255D%2520%253D%2520%255Cleft%255B%2520%255Cbegin%257Barray%257D%257Bcc%257D%25202%2520%2526%25201%2520%255C%255C%25201%2520%2526%25202%2520%255Cend%257Barray%257D%2520%255Cright%255D" alt="LaTeX: P^-[k] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array} \right]" data-equation-content="P^-[k] = \left[ \begin{array}{cc} 2 & 1 \\ 1 & 2 \end{array} \right]">,
what is the Kalman gain at time <img class="equation_image" title="k" src="/k" alt="LaTeX: k" data-equation-content="k">?

Given the system matrix:$$\mathbf{A} = \left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 0 & 0 \ 0 & -0.1 & 0 \ -1 & 1 & 0 \end{array} \right]$$

Which statement is correct about the internal stability and the
input-output stability of the system?
Unstable both internally and BIBO
Internally unstable, but BIBO stable
Stable both internally and BIBO
Internally unstable, and we need more information to determine BIBO
Internally stable, and we need more information to determine BIBO

Given the following continuous time system :$$\mathbf{\dot x} = \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 2 & -1 \ 0 & -1 \ \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 \ 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{B} u, \quad y = \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} 0 & 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{C} \mathbf{x}$$

Is this system:
Unstable (internally and in the input-output sense)
Exponentially stable
Marginally stable
BIBO stable

You need to model a noise process that has the spectral density function. Which of the following state space models, given a unity white noise input, will output a signal with the spectral density function matching ?

$$\dot x(t) = a x(t) + u(t), \quad a>0% \mathbf{\dot x} = \overbrace{\left[ % \begin{array}{ccc} % -1 & 1 \ % 0 & 0.5 % \end{array} % \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} + % \overbrace{\left[ % \begin{array}{cc} % 0 \ 1 % \end{array} % \right]}^\mathbf{B} u$$ This system is to be controlled using a state feedback . The feedback gain coefficient is to be chosen to minimize this objective function: $$J = \int_0^\infty q x(t)^2 + ru(t)^2 dt$$

What (if any) eigenvalue does the closed-loop system approach when stays constant and the input cost increases toward infinity, i.e. ?
Unstable (internally and in the input-output sense)
Exponentially stable
Marginally stable
BIBO stable, but not internally stable
Stability properties depend on

Given the following continuous time system : $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\dot x} =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & \alpha \ 0 & -0.5 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 \ 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{B} u \ y =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 0 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{C} \mathbf{x}\end{aligned}$$

where . You want to estimate the state values using an observer: $$\mathbf{\hat {\dot x}} = \mathbf{A \hat x} + \mathbf{B}u + \mathbf{L}(y - \mathbf{C \hat x})$$

What gain matrix should you use for the estimation error dynamics to have both eigenvalues equal to -5?
No choice of will achieve this.

Given the following continuous time system : $$\begin{aligned} \mathbf{\dot x} =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{ccc} -1 & \alpha \ 0 & \beta \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{A} \mathbf{x} + \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 0 \ 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{B} u \ y =& \overbrace{\left[ \begin{array}{cc} 1 & 1 \end{array} \right]}^\mathbf{C} \mathbf{x}\end{aligned}$$

What are the equations for this system on controllable canonical form?
